info.game_comments:
2012 Power Players Week game 4.
From DAR Constitution Hall in Washington, D.C.

(1, 1).clue: This TV sports spectacle premiered Monday, Sept. 21, 1970; are you ready?

(2, 1).clue: Thomas Sully painted the portrait of this man that's the basis for the $20 bill

(3, 1).clue: Military folk carry personal items in this large, cylindrical 6-letter "bag"

(4, 1).clue: Completes the John le Carre title, "Tinker, Tailor..."

(5, 1).clue: He entered Congress in 1995, 30 years after he & Cher topped the pop charts

(6, 1).clue: Term for films like "Catch-22" & "Dr. Strangelove", which juxtapose morbid elements with farce

(1, 2).clue: In the '90s she took wing with the album "Tuesday Night Music Club" & the hit "All I Wanna Do"

(2, 2).clue: This Impressionist painter was the father of Jean, director of "The Rules of the Game"

(3, 2).clue: Frequent travelers appreciate the tri-fold feature of Tumi's Presidio model of this bag

(4, 2).clue: Ann Charles sets creepy novels in this morbid-sounding South Dakota city

(5, 2).clue: Look out, Adam Sandler!  Senator Orrin Hatch's many songs include "Eight Days Of" this

(6, 2).clue: It's not church bells but "Hells Bells" that opens this AC/DC album

(1, 3).clue: Ash Wednesday is the first day of this religious period

(2, 3).clue: In depicting Native Americans, George Catlin often painted this beast, as in "Assiniboine Indians Pursuing" it "on Snowshoes"

(5, 3).clue: The 1998 album "Let Freedom Sing" is by The Singing Senators quartet, who specialized in this non-hair-raising vocal style

(6, 3).clue: Queen Anne's Revenge was this pirate's ship

(1, 4).clue: Thursday, Nov. 26, 1863 was proclaimed as "a day of" this "and praise"

(4, 4).clue: You presumed right if you think you're looking at this Chicago-born author of legal thrillers

(6, 4).clue: The Siksika are part of this Native American Confederacy

(1, 5).clue: Jason Voorhees is the hockey-masked psycho in this film franchise; don't go in the basement!

(1, 1).clue: In 2012 this encyclopedia announced it was discontinuing its 244-year-old print version & going online only

(2, 1).clue: nytimes.com velcomes you to the list of "The Best 1,000 Movies Ever Made", vich includes this 1931 Bela Lugosi film

(3, 1).clue: A 1950s senator who saw red:"Tail Gunner Joe"

(4, 1).clue: A term of endearment, like for my Clementine

(5, 1).clue: Article 47 of this European nation's constitution says "The confederation shall respect the autonomy of the cantons"

(6, 1).clue: A purse seine is a huge one of these that takes many fishermen (or a power block) to haul out of the water

(1, 2).clue: In 2011 this online retailer announced that its sales of e-books exceeded its sales of hardbacks & paperbacks

(2, 2).clue: nytimes.com links to reviews of the top 10 DVD rentals: this Brad Pitt film about "baseball in the digital age" hit No. 1 in 2012

(3, 2).clue: A 1920s president:"The Sphinx of the Potomac"

(4, 2).clue: The inner bull's eye is commonly worth 50 points in this game

(5, 2).clue: Excluding the 27 amendments, this country's constitution is among the world's shortest at just 4,426 words

(6, 2).clue: In the mid-1990s New York City broke the 40-year dominance of organized crime in the hauling of this

(1, 3).clue: This city's 146-year-old Post-Intelligencer went online only in 2009

(2, 3).clue: The nytimes.com movie archive has year-by-year "Critics' Picks": 1960 includes this mother of an Anthony Perkins pic

(4, 3).clue: This capital of Australia's Northern Territory is named for an evolutionary scientist

(5, 3).clue: He was emperor when Japan's "The emperor... shall not have powers related to government" was written

(6, 3).clue: In trucking, it's been defined as a run that covers more than 1,000 miles

(1, 4).clue: A phone-hacking scandal forced this British tabloid to close in 2011

(2, 4).clue: Stephen Holden noted this 17th c. title trio's return to the big screen in 2011 with "All for one, and then maybe a sequel"

(4, 4).clue: A longshot who wins, or a "Star Wars" comic book publisher

(5, 4).clue: Part III of its constitution prohibits discrimination on account of caste

(6, 4).clue: Also meaning a dopey person, it's from the Yiddish for "to haul", as in "for this I ____ed those books all the way here?"

(1, 5).clue: The web preserves the final edition of this "News" paper; it says, "Our time chronicling the life of Denver and Colorado... is over"

(2, 5).clue: Manohla Dargis titled the review of this 2011 drama "Finding the Humanity in the F.B.I.'s Feared Enforcer"

(4, 5).clue: It's the Turkish strait seen here

(6, 5).clue: "I presume" Chuma & Susi were the bearers who hauled this missionary around Africa, both alive & dead

(0, 0).clue: First held in May 1875, it is the oldest continuously held major sporting event in the United States
